title: We asked a few THON 2017 spectators: What ignites hope within you?

organizations.name: college of earth and mineral sciences

text:
Buy Now KC Black 
Maura Bacik (senior-nursing), participating with Apollo, stands in the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday, February 19, 2017. 
We asked spectators at THON 2017 what ignites hope within them. Here are their answers. 
Maura Bacik (senior-nursing) — Apollo 
“I’d say THON in general. It’s one of those topics where when people talk about it you get that feeling in your chest. It makes you so happy, and it makes your heart happy. Also, our two THON kids, Noah and Dev. I hung out with Dev all day today and she’s five years old. She’s such a little spitfire, so hanging out with them and seeing everything that they’ve been through and everything that they’ve conquered in their short lives is something that really inspires me and essentially inspires hope.” +12 
Adam Hornung (senior-political science), participating with Sigma Chi, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Adam Hornung (senior-political science) — Sigma Chi 
“That’s a loaded question. “I guess it’s like envisioning something greater than yourself and overcoming adversity. It’s succeeding in whatever you want to achieve." +12 
Dan Bollinger (senior-hospitality management), partcipating with Springfield, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Dan Bollinger (senior-hospitality management) — Springfield 
“What ignites hope within me is the possibility and what we’re all working towards here which is finding a cure for childhood cancer. Just letting these kids have a chance to one day live like the rest of us and do normal things that they maybe can’t do right now.” +12 
Bianca Angello (freshman-biology), participating with Atlas, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Bianca Angello (freshman-biology) — Atlas 
“I guess what ignites hope is, i suppose in a big school like this there are not a lot of things that bring people together from all these different backgrounds. What really ignites hope within me is all of us come out here regardless of our differences, and we all kind of connect over this one thing that all of us, not even some of us, can empathize with." +12 
Mike Gindhart (sophomore-economics), participating with Delta Sigma Phi, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Mike Gindhart (sophomore-economics) — Delta Sigma Phi 
“Kids different stories we’re seeing, and being able to talk to different families and see how much THON has done for them. I think that’s probably the biggest driver for me at THON every year.” +12 
Dennis Jacobs (freshman-aerospace engineering), participating with Theta Epsilon, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Dennis Jacobs (freshman-aerospace engineering) — Theta Epsilon 
“Everyone out here today makes me feel like I can make a difference. I’m just one person by myself, but with all these people here all coming together makes me feel bigger.” +12 
Doug Marsh (junior-supply chain management), participating with Axis, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Doug Marsh (junior-supply chain management) — Axis 
“All the kids that are here. They’re not all that fortunate, so it’s nice to be able to get out and put on this dance marathon for 46 hours -- giving them some hope and dancing for a cure. +12 
Maya Demvy (freshman-biology), participating with Surf State, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Maya Demvy (freshman-biology) — Serve State 
“Just knowing that there are people who are willing to do stuff like this for people that they don’t even know just because of the principle of the thing and knowing they’re helping someone else. That really inspires me. THON is the perfect example of that. +12 
Max Pessel (sophomore-engineering), participating with Pi Kappa Alpha, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Max Pessel (sophomore-engineering) — Pi Kappa Alpha 
“It’s just the fact that I know that we’re all contributing to a greater cause. It gives me inspiration to keep going.” +12 
Gabe Ferreri (sophomore-civil engineering), particpating Kappa Sigma, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Gabe Ferreri (sophomore-civil engineering) — Kappa Sigma 
“Hope for me, what ignites it is the promise of a better tomorrow and a future to look towards. That’s essentially what why I’m a part of this cause. You look at kids, and you know that they could have these long, prosperous futures ahead of them. They might not have that opportunity if they don’t receive these funds. Without hope, there is no looking forward to the next day in life.” +12 
Victoria Christenseon (junior-material science and engineering), participating with the College of Earth and Mineral Sciences, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Victoria Christenseon (junior-material science and engineering) — College of earth and mineral sciences - Captain 
“I think just the passion of my org ignites hope within me and my dancers. This whole weekend has just been introducing the freshman and transfer students to what THON is. We’re one college, one love, one fight. That’s what our saying is. Their passion feeds off me and ignites what I feel to my dancers.” +12 
Matt Ramjit (sophomore-finance and economics), participating with Phi Kappa Theta, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Matt Ramjit (sophomore-finance and economics) — Phi Kappa Theta 
“About a year ago, my mom passed away from cancer. So, I use that as inspiration to help other people out and help them through their tough times and whatever they need help with.” +12 
Mukesh Kambamaran (sophomore-IST), participating with Phi Sigma Kappa and Atlas, stands in the crowd at the Bryce Jordan Center for Penn State THON on Sunday February 19, 2017. KC Black 
Mukesh Kambamaran (sophomore-IST) — Phi Sigma Kappa and Atlas 
“What ignites hope within in me is the future and positivity. Definitely positivity.” 
Adam Groff (junior-kinesiology) — hospitality committee 
“What makes me hopeful is the hope that we will find a cure one day, and no kid will have to go through this again.”
